recipes.name: Nasi Lemak
instructions: Cook rice with coconut milk, pandan, lemongrass, and salt until fluffy.
Fry ikan bilis and peanuts separately until crispy.
Prepare or heat the sambal tumis.
Serve the fragrant rice with sambal, anchovies, peanuts, cucumber, and egg.

recipes.name: Chicken Rendang
ingredients: Spice Paste (chili, shallots, garlic, ginger, galangal, turmeric)
instructions: Sauté the spice paste until fragrant. Add chicken and cook until coated.
Stir in coconut cream, lemongrass, and other leaves.
Simmer slowly for 1.5 - 2 hours until the liquid reduces to a thick, rich paste (rendang). Stir in kerisik at the end.

recipes.name: Char Kway Teow (Penang Style)
ingredients: Soy Sauce (Dark & Light), Chili Paste, Pork Lard/Oil
instructions: Heat wok with oil until smoking hot ('Wok Hei').
Stir-fry prawns, sausage, and cockles quickly.
Add noodles, toss with sauces and chili paste.
Push aside, fry the egg, mix. Toss in bean sprouts and chives quickly before serving.

recipes.name: Asam Laksa
ingredients: Mint Leaves, Onion slices, Pineapple slices, Cucumber strips
instructions: Boil fish, debone, and shred the flesh. Reserve the broth.
Cook the laksa paste in the broth with asam keping and aromatics.
Add the shredded fish and simmer.
Serve the hot soup over rice noodles, garnished with fresh herbs/veg, and hae ko.

recipes.name: Roti Canai
instructions: Knead dough, portion, coat with oil, and rest for 2 hours.
Flatten and 'flip' the dough into a thin sheet. Fold into a square or round shape.
Pan-fry with oil/ghee until golden brown and crispy.
Serve immediately with curry or dahl.

recipes.name: Satay with Peanut Sauce
ingredients: Peanut Sauce (roasted peanuts, chili, tamarind, palm sugar, coconut milk)
instructions: Marinate meat, then thread onto skewers.
Grill over charcoal, basting lightly, until cooked.
Prepare the rich and thick peanut sauce.
Serve hot satay with peanut sauce, cucumber, and onion.

recipes.name: Hainanese Chicken Rice
ingredients: Ginger and Spring Onion dipping sauce
Chili sauce (chili, garlic, ginger, lime juice)
instructions: Poach the chicken. Use the chicken stock to cook the rice with aromatics.
Chop the chicken and drizzle with seasoned soy sauce.
Serve the chicken over the fragrant rice with sauces and soup.

recipes.name: Mee Goreng Mamak
ingredients: Dark Soy Sauce, Tomato Ketchup, Oyster Sauce
instructions: Heat oil in a wok and stir-fry the chili paste and protein/tofu.
Add vegetables and potatoes.
Toss in the yellow noodles, sauces, and a splash of water.
Scramble an egg into the wok and mix everything quickly.

recipes.name: Kuih Ketayap (Pandan Crepe)
ingredients: Crepe Batter (flour, eggs, coconut milk, pandan juice, salt)
Filling (Grated Coconut, Gula Melaka/Palm Sugar, Pandan Leaf, Water, Salt)
instructions: Cook the filling ingredients until the coconut is caramelized (Inti Kelapa).
Make thin green crepes on a non-stick pan.
Place filling on a crepe and roll it up. Serve at room temperature.

recipes.name: Ikan Bakar (Grilled Fish)
ingredients: Sambal Paste (chili, shallots, garlic, belacan, tamarind, turmeric)
instructions: Rub the fish with a generous amount of sambal paste.
Wrap the fish tightly in banana leaves.
Grill over hot charcoal or a grill pan until cooked through.
Serve with plain white rice.

recipes.name: Ayam Percik
ingredients: Sauce (Coconut milk, Lemongrass, Tamarind, Shallots, Chili, Ginger, Sugar, Salt)
instructions: Marinate the chicken and grill halfway.
Simmer the sauce ingredients until thick and reduced.
Baste the chicken repeatedly with the thick sauce while finishing the grill.
Serve with the remaining sauce poured over.

recipes.name: Curry Mee / Curry Laksa (Penang)
ingredients: Curry Paste (chili, turmeric, coriander, fennel, dried shrimp/belacan)
Chicken or Prawns, Tofu Puffs (Tau Pok)
instructions: Sauté curry paste. Add protein and cook.
Stir in coconut milk and stock; simmer. Add tofu puffs.
Pour hot soup over blanched noodles, garnished with toppings and sambal.

recipes.name: Pasembur / Indian Rojak
ingredients: Red Sweet Potato Gravy (chili, sweet potato, peanuts, tamarind, sugar)
instructions: Prepare all the fried fritters and chop into bite-sized pieces.
Mix the shredded vegetables and fritters.
Pour the thick, sweet, and spicy red gravy generously over the mix and toss.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Nasi Dagang
ingredients: Mixed Rice (white rice and glutinous rice)
Coconut Milk, Ginger, Shallots, Fenugreek Seeds (Halba)
instructions: Steam the mixed rice with aromatics and coconut milk.
Prepare a rich, red tuna curry (Gulai) as the main accompaniment.
Serve the warm rice with the tuna curry and pickled vegetables.

recipes.name: Ais Kacang (ABC)
ingredients: Rose Syrup, Evaporated Milk or Condensed Milk
instructions: Place assorted ingredients at the bottom of a bowl.
Pile a generous amount of finely shaved ice on top.
Drizzle with palm sugar syrup, rose syrup, and condensed milk.

recipes.name: Cendol
instructions: Add the Cendol jelly and red beans to a bowl.
Add a generous scoop of shaved ice.
Pour a large amount of Gula Melaka syrup and top with thick, chilled coconut milk.

recipes.name: Telur Bistik (Fried Egg Steak)
ingredients: Gravy (Tomato Ketchup, Worcestershire Sauce, Dark Soy Sauce, stock, cornstarch)
instructions: Prepare two sunny-side-up eggs.
Sauté the minced meat and vegetables. Pour in the gravy ingredients and simmer.
Place the fried egg on a plate, pour the savory gravy over it.
Garnish with peas and french fries.

recipes.name: Prawn Sambal (Sambal Udang)
ingredients: Sambal Paste (chili, shallots, belacan, tamarind, garlic)
instructions: Sauté the sambal paste and onions in hot oil until fragrant (Pecah Minyak).
Add the prawns, tamarind juice, salt, and palm sugar.
Cook until the prawns are pink and the sauce is glossy and thick.
Serve hot with plain rice.

recipes.name: Popiah (Fresh Spring Rolls)
instructions: Slow-cook the shredded turnip until soft and drained.
Lay out a popiah skin, spread with sauces.
Layer with turnip, egg, and garnish. Roll up tightly and slice.

recipes.name: Kaya Toast
instructions: Toast the bread slices until crispy.
Spread a generous layer of Kaya on one slice.
Place cold, thick slices of butter on top of the Kaya.
Top with the second slice of toast and slice in half. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Laksa Sarawak
ingredients: Laksa Sarawak Paste (chili, galangal, lemongrass, tamarind)
instructions: Prepare a fragrant chicken stock by simmering bones and aromatics for at least 30 minutes. Strain and set aside.
Blanch the rice vermicelli according to package directions until al dente. Drain and set in serving bowls.
Sauté the Laksa Sarawak paste (or the spice blend) in a large pot until very fragrant and the oil separates (pecah minyak).
Pour in the chicken stock and bring the mixture to a slow boil.
Stir in the thick coconut milk, ensuring it doesn't curdle, and simmer gently for 20 minutes to allow the flavors to deepen.
In a separate pot, quickly blanch the prawns and set aside.
Season the broth with salt, sugar, and more tamarind or lime juice if needed.
Place a portion of bean sprouts, shredded chicken, shredded egg omelette, and the blanched prawns over the noodles.
Ladle the hot Laksa broth generously over the ingredients.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve immediately with a lime wedge and a side of chili sambal for extra heat.

recipes.name: Manok Pansoh (Bamboo Chicken)
instructions: Cut the chicken into uniform, bite-sized chunks and clean thoroughly.
In a large bowl, combine the chicken with the sliced ginger, galangal, bruised lemongrass, minced garlic, salt, and pepper.
Marinate the chicken for at least 30 minutes to absorb the strong aromatic flavors.
Wash and roughly chop the tapioca leaves (or substitute with spinach or basil if unavailable).
Gently mix the tapioca leaves into the marinated chicken.
Carefully stuff the chicken and leaf mixture into the hollow bamboo culm, packing it slightly but not too tightly.
Pour 1/4 cup of water or chicken stock into the bamboo to keep the dish moist during cooking.
Seal the top of the bamboo with a wad of leftover tapioca leaves or a large banana leaf plug.
Place the bamboo diagonally over a gentle wood fire or hot embers. Turn it every 15-20 minutes to ensure even cooking.
Cook for approximately 1.5 hours, or until the bamboo is charred and the chicken is tender and fully cooked.
To serve, carefully split the bamboo or tip the contents out onto a serving plate. Serve with plain rice.

recipes.name: Otak-Otak (Grilled Fish Cake)
ingredients: Otak-Otak Spice Paste (chili, turmeric, galangal, lemongrass, shallots)
instructions: Prepare the spice paste by blending fresh chili, turmeric, galangal, lemongrass, and shallots until smooth.
In a large bowl, combine the fish paste with the spice paste, coconut milk, beaten egg, tapioca starch, and shredded kaffir lime leaves.
Mix thoroughly by hand or spatula until the mixture is smooth and slightly sticky; season with salt and sugar.
Test the seasoning: steam a small teaspoon of the mixture for 1 minute and taste. Adjust as needed.
Lay out a piece of banana leaf (shiny side up) and place a large spoonful (about 50g) of the fish mixture in the center.
Fold the banana leaf into a tight rectangular packet, securing the ends with toothpicks or metal staples.
Pre-steam the wrapped packets for 5 minutes. This step firms up the fish cake and ensures it is cooked through.
Preheat a grill pan or charcoal grill to medium-high heat.
Place the steamed packets directly onto the hot grill.
Grill for 3-5 minutes on each side until the banana leaf is slightly charred, imparting a smoky aroma and flavor to the fish cake.
Remove from the heat and serve the Otak-Otak hot, unwrapped at the table.

recipes.name: Apam Balik (Peanut Pancake)
ingredients: Batter (Flour, Eggs, Sugar, Coconut Milk/Milk, Baking Soda)
Filling (Crushed Roasted Peanuts, Granulated Sugar, Creamed Sweet Corn, Butter/Margarine)
instructions: Prepare the thin, flowable batter by whisking together the flour, sugar, eggs, milk, and raising agents. Let the batter rest for at least 30 minutes to activate the leavening.
Preheat a large, heavy-bottomed pan or griddle over medium-low heat. Brush lightly with oil or butter.
Pour a generous ladle of batter into the center of the pan, spreading it slightly to form a large, thick, circular pancake.
Cover the pan and cook for 3-4 minutes until bubbles appear across the surface and the edges set.
Once the bubbles pop and the surface looks semi-cooked, sprinkle granulated sugar evenly over the entire surface.
Quickly dot the surface with cubes of butter or margarine, ensuring it melts into the pancake.
Generously spread the creamed sweet corn over one half of the pancake.
Evenly sprinkle a thick layer of crushed roasted peanuts on top of the sweet corn layer.
Cook uncovered for 1-2 more minutes, or until the bottom is golden brown and the toppings are warm.
Carefully fold the pancake in half using a spatula, creating a semi-circle.
Remove the Apam Balik from the pan, brush the top crust with more butter, and slice it into 2-inch wide pieces immediately before serving hot.

recipes.name: Ikan Masak Tiga Rasa (Three-Flavor Fish)
ingredients: 1 Whole Fish (e.g., Seabass/Siakap or Snapper), cleaned and scored
Tiga Rasa Sauce (Tomato Ketchup, Chili Sauce, Tamarind/Vinegar)
Sauce Aromatics (Garlic, Ginger, Chili, Onion, Lemongrass)
instructions: Clean and score the fish deeply. Pat it completely dry, then season generously with salt and turmeric powder.
Heat a wok with oil until very hot (about 180°C/350°F).
Carefully deep-fry the fish for 5-8 minutes per side, turning gently, until it is golden brown and crispy on the outside and cooked through.
Remove the fish and place it on a serving plate lined with paper towels to drain excess oil.
Discard most of the oil from the wok, leaving about 2 tablespoons.
In the same wok, sauté the chopped garlic, ginger, chilies, and onion until fragrant.
Add the main Tiga Rasa liquid ingredients: tomato ketchup, chili sauce, tamarind juice, a little water, sugar, and salt.
Bring the sauce to a slow boil, allowing it to thicken slightly. Add the pineapple chunks, if using.
Taste the sauce to ensure the balance of three flavors: **sweet** (sugar/ketchup), **sour** (tamarind/vinegar), and **spicy** (chili sauce). Adjust as needed.
Pour the hot Tiga Rasa sauce generously over the crispy fried fish.
Garnish immediately with fresh cilantro and spring onion slices.
Serve hot with steamed white rice.

recipes.name: Mee Siam (Dry Malaysian Style)
ingredients: Mee Siam Paste (Dried shrimp, chili, tamarind, shallots, belacan)
Soy Sauce, Fish Sauce, Palm Sugar
instructions: Soak the rice vermicelli in hot water for 5 minutes until soft but still firm; drain well and set aside.
Prepare the Mee Siam paste by blending dried shrimp, chilies, shallots, and belacan until smooth.
Heat oil in a wok and sauté the Mee Siam paste until fragrant and the oil separates (pecah minyak).
Add the sliced chicken and cook until it changes color; then add the prawns and cook until pink.
Push the ingredients to one side of the wok and add a little more oil to scramble the eggs. Mix the cooked egg into the other ingredients.
Add the softened rice vermicelli to the wok and toss quickly to coat it completely with the paste.
Season the noodles with light soy sauce, fish sauce, palm sugar, and a little tamarind juice for tang.
Toss everything vigorously over high heat, ensuring the noodles are evenly colored and seasoned.
Add the bean sprouts and the chopped chives to the wok.
Toss for one last minute until the vegetables are just wilted but still crunchy.
Serve the Mee Siam immediately, typically garnished with crispy fried shallots, a lime wedge, and sometimes a hard-boiled egg or small fried tofu cubes.

recipes.name: Bubur Cha Cha
ingredients: 1 cup Mixed colored Tapioca Jellies (Nyonya style)
Palm Sugar (Gula Melaka) and Granulated Sugar to taste
instructions: Peel and cube the sweet potatoes and taro. Boil them separately until they are almost tender but still hold their shape.
Soak the sago pearls in water, then boil until translucent. Drain and rinse with cold water to prevent sticking.
In a large pot, combine the thick and thin coconut milk/water with the knotted pandan leaves and a pinch of salt.
Bring the mixture to a very gentle simmer over medium-low heat, stirring constantly to prevent the coconut milk from curdling.
Add the cubed sweet potatoes and taro to the simmering coconut milk mixture.
Add the palm sugar (Gula Melaka) and granulated sugar. Continue to stir until the sugar is completely dissolved.
Simmer for 10-15 minutes, or until the sweet potatoes and taro are completely soft and the sauce has thickened slightly.
Add the cooked sago pearls and the mixed colored tapioca jellies (or other Nyonya dessert ingredients).
Stir gently and heat through for another 2-3 minutes.
Remove the pandan leaves before serving.
Bubur Cha Cha can be served warm immediately, or chilled in the refrigerator for a refreshing cold dessert.

recipes.name: Prawn Noodle Soup (Penang Hokkien Mee)
ingredients: Pork ribs or Chicken carcass (for stock base)
Chili paste (sambal), fried shallots, garlic, dried shrimp
Hard-boiled eggs, Water spinach (kangkung), Bean Sprouts
instructions: Prepare the prawn stock: rinse the prawn shells and heads. Fry them in oil with dried shrimp and chili paste until fragrant.
Add pork ribs/chicken carcass and a large amount of water. Simmer for at least 1.5 hours, skimming the foam and fat, to create a deep, rich red stock.
While the stock simmers, prepare the toppings: cook the yellow noodles and rice vermicelli separately, and blanch the water spinach and bean sprouts.
In a small pan, fry sliced shallots until crispy. Reserve the oil and the crispy shallots for garnish.
Strain the prawn stock thoroughly, pressing on the shells and heads to extract maximum flavor. Season the broth with salt, pepper, and sugar.
Quickly blanch the peeled prawns in the broth until they are just cooked; set the prawns aside.
Assemble the serving bowls: place a portion of yellow noodles and vermicelli in each bowl.
Arrange the blanched kangkung, bean sprouts, and sliced hard-boiled egg on top of the noodles.
Arrange the peeled prawns and slices of pork (if using) on the side.
Ladle the piping hot, deeply flavored prawn broth over the noodles and toppings.
Garnish generously with fried shallots and a dollop of chili sambal (optional). Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Nasi Kerabu (Blue Rice)
ingredients: 3 cups Rice, colored blue with Bunga Telang (Butterfly Pea Flowers)
Kerabu (Herb Salad: long beans, bean sprouts, cabbage, daun kesum)
Ayam Percik (Grilled Chicken) or Daging Bakar (Grilled Beef)
instructions: Steep the dried Butterfly Pea Flowers (Bunga Telang) in hot water to extract a deep blue color.
Wash the rice and cook it using the blue-colored water, either by steaming or using a rice cooker.
Prepare the Kerabu by finely slicing or chopping the fresh herbs and vegetables (long beans, shredded cabbage, *daun kesum*).
Make the seasoning mix: combine kerisik (toasted coconut paste), chili paste, lime juice, and fish sauce/salt.
Just before serving, lightly toss the chopped Kerabu herbs with the kerisik seasoning mix.
Prepare the accompaniments: deep-fry the fish crackers (Keropok) and slice the salted egg.
If using, grill the chicken (*Ayam Percik*) or beef (*Daging Bakar*).
To assemble, mound a portion of the blue rice on a plate.
Place a generous amount of the fresh Kerabu herb salad next to the rice.
Arrange the Keropok, a half salted egg, a spoonful of Sambal Tumis, and the grilled meat (Ayam Percik).
Add a drizzle of the savory *Budu* (fermented fish sauce) or plain coconut milk gravy (Kuah Tumis) for richness.
Serve the dish immediately, as the herbs are best when fresh and crunchy.

recipes.name: Kari Ayam Kapitan (Nyonya Captain's Curry)
ingredients: Spice Paste (Turmeric, Galangal, Shallots, Chili, Lemongrass, Dried Shrimp)
2 Tbsp Tamarind Pulp, soaked in water (or Asam Keping)
instructions: Prepare the wet spice paste by blending or grinding all the spice ingredients (turmeric, galangal, shallots, etc.) until very fine and smooth.
Heat a wok or large pot with cooking oil and sauté the spice paste over low to medium heat.
Continue frying the paste for 10-15 minutes, stirring frequently, until it darkens in color and the oil separates (pecah minyak). This is crucial for flavor.
Add the chicken pieces to the wok and stir well to ensure every piece is completely coated with the fragrant spice paste.
Add the water from the tamarind pulp (discarding the pulp) or the *asam keping* (tamarind slices).
Pour in the thick coconut milk, stirring immediately to combine with the paste and prevent it from curdling.
Add the kaffir lime leaves, palm sugar, and salt.
Bring the curry to a gentle simmer, then reduce the heat, cover, and let it cook for 30 minutes, or until the chicken is tender and the sauce has thickened significantly.
Adjust the seasoning at the end, adding more sugar for sweetness or tamarind for sourness. It should have a rich balance of sweet, sour, and savory.
To serve, garnish with fresh, finely shredded kaffir lime leaves or a little cilantro.
Serve hot with steamed white rice, Nasi Lemak, or Roti Jala.

recipes.name: Sayur Lodeh (Vegetable Curry)
ingredients: Variety of vegetables (Long beans, Cabbage, Carrots, Eggplant, Tempeh, Tofu)
Lodeh Spice Paste (Turmeric, Shallots, Garlic, Galangal, Chili, Dried Shrimp)
instructions: Prepare all vegetables by cutting them into uniform, bite-sized pieces. Slice the tempeh and cut the tofu into cubes.
Prepare the spice paste by blending the shallots, garlic, galangal, turmeric, and chili (and dried shrimp if using) until smooth.
Heat oil in a pot and sauté the spice paste along with the bruised lemongrass and galangal until fragrant.
Pour in the thin coconut milk and water/stock. Bring the mixture to a slow boil.
Add the harder vegetables first (carrots, long beans, tempeh, taro if using). Cook for about 10 minutes until partially softened.
Add the softer vegetables, like cabbage, eggplant, and tofu. Continue simmering.
Stir in the thick coconut milk and the tamarind paste/asam keping. Reduce heat immediately to a gentle simmer.
Season generously with salt, sugar, and a little chicken stock powder (optional) until the flavor is rich and well-balanced.
Continue to cook gently for another 10 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent curdling, until all vegetables are tender.
Do not overcook the dish; the vegetables should retain some texture and color.
Serve the Sayur Lodeh warm, often alongside Lontong (compressed rice cakes) or plain white rice.

recipes.name: Cucur Udang (Prawn Fritters)
ingredients: 1 cup Chopped Onion, Chives, and/or Bean Sprouts
instructions: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, turmeric powder, baking powder, and salt.
Gradually whisk in the egg and water until you have a smooth, thick batter slightly thinner than pancake batter.
Stir in the finely chopped onions, chives, and/or bean sprouts into the batter.
Heat a large wok or deep pot with at least 3 inches of oil to 175°C (345°F).
Dip a large ladle or specially designed frying ring into the hot oil to heat it up. This prevents the batter from sticking.
Scoop a spoonful of batter into the hot ladle/ring. You may use a second ladle to help shape it.
Place a few small, whole prawns (shell on) on top of the batter in the ladle.
Carefully submerge the ladle into the hot oil. After about 30 seconds, the fritter will loosen and float away from the ladle.
Fry the fritters for about 4-6 minutes, turning once, until they are golden brown and crispy.
Remove the fritters and drain them on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve the Cucur Udang immediately while hot, traditionally with a spicy-sweet chili dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Sambal Petai with Prawns
ingredients: 1 cup Petai (Stink Beans), peeled and halved
Sambal Paste (Chili, Shallots, Garlic, Belacan, Dried Shrimp)
1 Tbsp Tamarind Paste, mixed with water
Palm Sugar (Gula Melaka) and Salt to taste
instructions: Prepare the Sambal paste by blending the chilies, shallots, garlic, dried shrimp, and belacan (shrimp paste) until smooth.
Soak tamarind paste in a little hot water and squeeze out the juice. Set aside.
Heat a wok with cooking oil and sauté the Sambal paste over medium heat.
Fry the paste for 10-12 minutes, stirring constantly, until it darkens and the oil separates (pecah minyak). This develops the flavor.
Add the sliced onion and cook until softened.
Add the petai (stink beans) and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes. Do not overcook; the petai should remain slightly crunchy.
Add the peeled prawns to the wok and toss immediately with the sambal.
Stir in the tamarind juice, palm sugar, and salt. Cook until the sugar dissolves and the sauce thickens slightly.
Continue cooking for another 3-5 minutes, or until the prawns are fully cooked, pink, and firm.
Taste and adjust the balance between spicy, sour, and sweet as needed.
Serve the Sambal Petai Udang hot, as a potent side dish to be eaten with plain rice.

recipes.name: Nyonya Acar (Pickled Vegetables)
ingredients: 1 cup Long Beans, cut into 1-inch lengths
Acar Paste (Chili, Shallots, Garlic, Turmeric, Ginger, Belacan-optional)
instructions: Prepare the vegetables (cucumber, carrots, long beans) by slicing or cutting them into uniform strips/lengths.
Blanch the carrots and long beans briefly in boiling water (about 1 minute) to retain crunch, then immediately plunge them into an ice bath.
Pat the blanched and unblanched vegetables completely dry to prevent the final acar from being watery.
Prepare the spice paste by blending the chilies, shallots, garlic, turmeric, and ginger until smooth. (Omit belacan for vegetarian).
Heat a wok with oil and sauté the spice paste over medium-low heat until fragrant, ensuring the turmeric is cooked out.
Stir in the vinegar, sugar, and salt. Bring the sauce to a boil and taste to achieve a perfect balance of sweet, sour, and spicy.
Remove the sauce from the heat and allow it to cool completely to maintain the crunchiness of the vegetables.
In a large bowl, combine the dried vegetables and pineapple cubes.
Pour the cooled Acar sauce over the vegetables and toss everything thoroughly to coat.
Stir in most of the crushed roasted peanuts, reserving some for garnish.
Transfer the Acar to an airtight container and chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, or preferably overnight, before serving.
Garnish with the remaining crushed peanuts just before serving as a cold accompaniment.

recipes.name: Nasi Goreng Kampung
ingredients: Dark Soy Sauce, Fish Sauce, Salt
instructions: Ensure rice is cold and separated to prevent clumping during frying.
Heat a wok with oil and fry the dried anchovies until crispy. Remove the anchovies and set them aside, reserving the oil.
In the same wok, stir-fry the chopped prawns and any other meat until partially cooked.
Push the ingredients to one side, add a little more oil, crack in the egg, and scramble it quickly. Mix into the meat/prawns.
Add 1-2 tablespoons of the Sambal paste and stir-fry for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add the cold rice to the wok and break up any lumps. Toss vigorously over high heat to achieve a smoky *Wok Hei* flavor.
Season the rice generously with dark soy sauce (for color and flavor), fish sauce, and salt.
Stir-fry until the rice grains are uniformly colored and hot.
Toss in the chopped leafy greens (Kangkung) and cook until they are just wilted (about 1 minute).
Quickly mix in the reserved crispy anchovies (Ikan Bilis).
Serve the Nasi Goreng Kampung immediately, often garnished with a fried egg (Telur Mata Kerbau) and cucumber slices.
For extra flavor, squeeze a wedge of lime over the rice just before eating.

recipes.name: Ikan Patin Masak Tempoyak
ingredients: 400g Patin Fish (Silver Catfish), cut into steaks
instructions: Prepare the spice base (*Bumbu*) by blending the bird's eye chilies and fresh turmeric root (or powder) with a little water until smooth.
In a medium pot, combine the spice base, the bruised lemongrass, and the Tempoyak (fermented durian paste).
Add about 1 cup of water or thin coconut milk and bring the mixture to a slow boil, stirring frequently to combine the Tempoyak.
Once boiling, reduce the heat and simmer for 10-15 minutes to cook the chili paste and deepen the flavor.
Season the gravy with salt and sugar. The gravy should be hot, slightly sour (from fermentation), and intensely savory.
Gently add the Patin fish steaks into the simmering gravy. Use a fish spatula to avoid breaking the delicate fish flesh.
If using, add a few pineapple slices, which naturally pair well with the durian flavor.
Continue simmering gently for 8-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and the gravy has thickened slightly.
Do not stir too vigorously once the fish is added.
Taste and adjust seasoning; the durian flavor should be prominent but balanced by the chili and seasonings.
Remove from heat and serve immediately while the gravy is still hot.
Serve as a main dish with plenty of plain white rice.

recipes.name: Kek Lapis Sarawak (Sarawak Layer Cake)
ingredients: Flour, Vanilla Extract, various Food Colorings/Flavorings (e.g., chocolate, pandan)
instructions: Preheat the oven to a medium temperature (around 150°C/300°F). Grease and line an 8x8 inch square baking tin.
Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Gradually add the beaten egg yolks, followed by the condensed milk, mixing well after each addition.
In a separate bowl, beat the egg whites until stiff peaks form.
Gently fold the dry ingredients (sifted flour) into the egg yolk mixture, then carefully fold in the stiff egg whites to create a light batter.
Divide the batter evenly into several bowls (usually 4-8), coloring and flavoring each portion as desired (e.g., green, red, brown).
Spoon the first layer (about 100g) of one color of batter into the prepared tin and spread it evenly.
Bake the first layer for 5-7 minutes, or until the top is set and slightly golden.
Once cooked, gently press the surface of the first layer with a flat tool (e.g., a cake press) to compact it.
Switch the oven to the broiler/grill function. Spoon the second layer (a different color) onto the first.
Broil the second layer for 3-5 minutes until golden brown. Repeat the pressing step.
Continue layering and broiling, alternating colors and pressing after each layer, until all the batter is used.
After the final layer, switch back to the bake function and bake the whole cake for 10-15 minutes to fully set the interior.
Cool the cake completely before slicing into geometric patterns. It tastes best the next day.

recipes.name: Popiah Basah (Wet Spring Rolls)
instructions: Prepare the main filling by stewing finely shredded turnip and carrot in a little water or stock until very soft and tender. Drain well.
Season the stewed turnip lightly with salt, pepper, and sometimes a little light soy sauce or oyster sauce (optional).
Prepare the garnishes: hard-boil and shred the eggs, crush the peanuts, and set aside the fried shallots.
Lay out a sheet of Popiah skin on a clean surface.
First, spread a thin layer of the sweet sauce (and garlic paste, if using) across the entire skin.
Next, spread a thin layer of chili sauce over the sweet sauce (adjusting for desired heat).
Place a spoonful of the stewed, drained turnip and carrot filling horizontally across the bottom third of the skin.
Layer the filling with shredded hard-boiled egg and a sprinkle of crushed roasted peanuts and crispy fried shallots.
Fold the left and right sides of the skin inwards over the filling.
Roll the skin tightly from the bottom upwards into a cylinder shape.
Once rolled, the Popiah Basah can be sliced into two or three pieces for easy serving.
Serve immediately, as it is meant to be eaten fresh before the skin dries out.

recipes.name: Kerabu Mangga (Green Mango Salad)
ingredients: Handful of Mint and Coriander leaves
Dressing (Fish Sauce, Lime Juice, Palm Sugar)
Toasted Belacan (Shrimp Paste, optional), Crushed Peanuts (optional)
instructions: Peel and shred the green mangoes into thin strips. The mango should be firm and sour.
Thinly slice the red onion and red bell pepper (or use cucumber/carrots for color and crunch).
Roughly chop the fresh mint and coriander leaves. Combine all vegetables and herbs in a large bowl.
Prepare the dressing by whisking together the fish sauce (or soy sauce/salt for vegan), fresh lime juice, and dissolved palm sugar.
The dressing must achieve a balanced flavor: intensely sour, sweet, and savory/salty.
Finely chop the bird's eye chilies. Add them to the dressing, adjusting the amount to your desired level of heat.
If using Belacan (shrimp paste), toast a small piece until fragrant, crumble it, and mix it into the dressing for an umami depth.
Pour the dressing over the shredded mango mixture.
Gently toss the salad until all the ingredients are evenly coated with the dressing.
Stir in the crushed peanuts (if using) just before serving to maintain their crunch.
Serve the Kerabu Mangga immediately as a refreshing, spicy, and tangy side dish to rich curries and fried fish.

recipes.name: Lontong (Compressed Rice Cakes)
ingredients: Banana Leaves (or aluminum foil) for wrapping
Sayur Lodeh (Vegetable Curry, see previous recipe for details)
Hard-boiled eggs, Crispy fried anchovies (Ikan Bilis)
instructions: To make the Lontong: wash the rice and drain well. For traditional cooking, pack the rice tightly into a long banana leaf wrap, leaving room for expansion.
Alternatively, use a special Lontong mould or pack rice tightly into small containers wrapped in foil/plastic wrap.
Boil the packed rice (Lontong) submerged in water for 1.5 to 2 hours. This process creates a firm, compressed rice cake.
Remove the Lontong from the boiling water, drain well, and let it cool completely for several hours (or overnight) until the rice is rock-hard and set. Slice into cubes when cold.
Prepare the key accompanying dishes: **Sayur Lodeh** (vegetable curry in coconut milk) and **Sambal Goreng** (chili-fried tofu, tempeh, and long beans).
Prepare the garnishes: hard-boil the eggs, and fry the anchovies until crispy.
To assemble the Lontong dish: place a generous amount of sliced, cold Lontong cubes in a deep serving bowl.
Pour a large ladle of the warm Sayur Lodeh (vegetable curry) over the rice cubes.
Add a generous portion of Sambal Goreng (the fried tofu/tempeh mix).
Garnish with a half hard-boiled egg, crispy fried anchovies, and a spoonful of Serunding (if using).
Serve immediately, usually for breakfast or a hearty lunch.

recipes.name: Putu Mayam (String Hoppers)
ingredients: Garnishes (Freshly Grated Coconut, Palm Sugar/Gula Melaka, Sugar)
instructions: Combine the rice flour, tapioca flour, and a pinch of salt in a large heatproof mixing bowl.
Gradually pour in the hot water, stirring continuously until the mixture comes together into a rough, soft dough.
Knead the dough lightly by hand for 5-10 minutes until it is smooth and pliable.
Prepare the steamer. Line the steaming racks with banana leaves or parchment paper and lightly grease them.
Transfer the dough into a special string hopper press (or a large piping bag with multiple small holes).
Press the dough directly onto the prepared steaming racks in circular, nest-like patterns.
If desired, place a small amount of freshly grated coconut on top of the raw pressed noodles.
Steam the *Putu Mayam* nests for 5-7 minutes, or until the noodles are set and cooked through.
While steaming, combine the grated coconut with a mixture of granulated sugar and shredded *Gula Melaka* (palm sugar).
Carefully remove the cooked nests from the steamer using a spatula.
Serve the warm *Putu Mayam* immediately with a generous helping of the sweetened grated coconut mixture.
The contrast between the warm, plain rice noodles and the sweet, sandy coconut is key.

recipes.name: Briyani Ghee Rice (Nasi Briyani Ghee)
ingredients: Whole Spices (Cinnamon sticks, Cardamom pods, Cloves, Star Anise)
instructions: Wash the Basmati rice thoroughly until the water runs clear. Soak the rice for 30 minutes, then drain.
Heat the ghee in a large, heavy-bottomed pot or a thick-based rice cooker pot.
Add the whole spices (cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, star anise) and fry for about 30 seconds until very fragrant.
Add the sliced onion and sauté until golden brown and caramelized.
Stir in the minced ginger and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add the soaked and drained Basmati rice to the pot. Gently stir-fry the rice with the spices for 2-3 minutes until the grains are coated and smell nutty.
Pour in the measured water or chicken stock (usually 1.5 times the rice volume). Add a pinch of salt.
Add a handful of chopped coriander and mint leaves.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce the heat to the lowest setting.
Stir in a splash of evaporated milk or cream (optional) for richness.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid (or seal with foil for a proper *dum* method).
Cook for 15-20 minutes until all the liquid is absorbed and the rice is light and fluffy. Do not lift the lid during this time.
Fluff the rice gently with a fork before serving. Serve hot as an accompaniment to Chicken Rendang or Kari Ayam.

recipes.name: Sambal Goreng Jawa
ingredients: 1 cup Long Beans, cut into 1-inch lengths
instructions: Cut the tempeh and firm tofu into small cubes. Deep-fry them separately until golden brown and crispy. Drain and set aside.
Prepare the Sambal paste by blending the chilies, shallots, and garlic until smooth. (Add belacan or dried shrimp if not making vegetarian).
Heat a wok with cooking oil and sauté the Sambal paste over medium heat for 10 minutes until fragrant and the oil separates.
Add the long beans and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until they are bright green and slightly tender-crisp.
Stir in the tamarind juice and the palm sugar, mixing well until the sugar dissolves and the sauce is glossy.
Pour in a generous amount of Dark Sweet Soy Sauce (*Kicap Manis*).
Add the fried tempeh and tofu cubes to the wok and toss everything quickly and gently to coat all the pieces with the thick, dark sauce.
Continue to stir-fry for 3-5 minutes until the sauce is reduced and clinging thickly to the tempeh and tofu.
Taste and adjust the balance of sweet, spicy, and savory flavors. It should be rich and slightly sticky.
If using, stir in a handful of fried crispy dried anchovies (Ikan Bilis) at the very end.
Serve warm as a popular side dish, often with Sayur Lodeh and Lontong.

recipes.name: Tauhu Sumbat (Stuffed Tofu)
ingredients: 8 pieces Firm Tofu Puffs (Tauhu Pok), fried and hollowed
Dipping Sauce (Peanuts, Chili, Garlic, Tamarind, Palm Sugar, Water)
instructions: Use firm tofu puffs (*Tauhu Pok*). Cut a slit along one side of each puff and gently scoop out some of the spongy interior to create a pocket.
Prepare the filling: finely shred the cucumber and carrots. Blanch the bean sprouts briefly to remove the raw taste, then cool.
Mix the shredded vegetables and bean sprouts in a bowl. Season lightly with salt and pepper.
Prepare the dipping sauce: blend or grind roasted peanuts, chilies, garlic, tamarind, and palm sugar.
Transfer the blended sauce ingredients to a saucepan, add water, and simmer gently for 5-10 minutes until the sauce thickens and the sugar dissolves.
Adjust the sauce to taste—it should be sweet, spicy, nutty, and slightly sour from the tamarind.
Generously stuff the pocket of each tofu puff with the mixed raw vegetable filling.
Arrange the stuffed tofu puffs on a serving platter.
The tofu can be served cold/room temperature, or you can gently steam them for 2-3 minutes to warm the filling slightly.
Spoon the warm or room temperature peanut sauce over the tofu, or serve the sauce on the side for dipping.
Garnish with a sprinkle of chopped peanuts or fresh coriander.
Serve immediately as a light and refreshing protein-packed snack.
